author: KD23
title: Hospice was like our 2nd home
body:
My mum was diagnosed with terminal cancer in lockdown and was cared for in the hospice before she passed away. This was a very difficult time for our family but the Kilbryde staff helped us make the best of our time. My mum adored every one of the staff and often said how safe she felt in their care. The staff are professional yet at the same time they really did feel like family.  
Even with lockdown restrictions in place the hospice did everything they could to support safe visits which was amazing after not seeing my mum for 2 months after she was in hospital during lockdown.  
The hospice staff organised so many meaningful events for us to create special memories like a movie night and birthday celebrations. In my mums last week of care we celebrated the birth of her granddaughter. The staff made this feel like such a special time for us all and I was so glad my mum got to meet her before she passed away.  
We will never be able to repay the care received to my mum, but we will always be so grateful and continue to support the hospice.  
Although they could not change the outcome, they really did affect the journey. Thank you all so much x

readBy.name: Sheffield University Medical School 2022
Kilbryde Hospice
Scottish Government

author: Archie Hugo
title: You should all be so proud of yourselves
body:
I was admitted through A & E to ward 4 at Hairmyres Hospital, in September.  
Every member of staff that I had contact with from the receptionist at A & E, the porters , the X-ray and CT staff, A &E nurses ,Doctors , auxiliaries and domestic were all fantastic.  
I arrived in ward 4 in the middle of the night. The staff were welcoming, friendly, informative. In the morning the domestic, who bought my breakfast, was so nice. She kept us going all day with tea and some chat.  
The nurse who was looking after me, Lucy, was amazing. She was professional and kept me informed about my care , taking time to explain everything to me. The auxiliaries on the ward would pop in to see if anyone in my bay needed anything.  
All of the staff in every part of the hospital were run off their feet. And some how managed to remain friendly, professional, and informative at all times.  
I would like to thank each and everyone that was involved in my care. You should all be so proud of yourselves. Thank you

readBy.name: NHS Lanarkshire

author: Caziz
title: Unable to get an appointment to see the doctor
body:
Each time I phone for a doctor am told there is a lot of callers and the phone is cut off. I don't have an NHS app and I am not going on line to register more details. I've already sent a complaint to the practice manager but had no reply. What should be a very simple procedure is now a nightmare and wastes a lot of time. How do people at work, with small kids, elderly, disabled etc. manage this? How about bringing human beings back and dealing directly with patients - and not from a call centre?  
Medical centres have been built on community and interaction.  
God help us.

author: friendly-neighbourhood-fox
title: Good doctors, unhelpful reception staff
body:
I have had good experiences with the doctors here, however the reception staff have repeatedly been unhelpful to me when I required their support.  
I understand that resources can be scarce, and that the job can be stressful but I feel that they take it out on vulnerable patients and that this is wholly unacceptable.

author: equuleusmr64
title: Skin cancer treatment
body:
Awful service when waiting for suspected skin cancer.  
I had 2 skin cancers removed from my nose 4 years ago and luckily this was done in Guys.  
In October 2021, my GP referred me to Basildon Hospital Dermatologist for a suspected skin cancer on my nose and back.  
I attended a dermatology appointment via Basildon Hospital Dermatology Dept in January 2022. The dermatologist confirmed it looks like 2 skin cancers on my nose and also the lesion on my back. She said both on my nose must be done in Basildon Hospital as it’s the face and the one on my back can be removed in the clinic.  
In March 2022, I attended Rayleigh Clinic and had the one on my back removed. I asked the surgeon to do a biopsy of the 2 on my face but he said he would not be allowed to do this.  
I complained to PALS as the 2 I had removed by Guys was completed within a couple of weeks from the initial referral. The dermatologist called me up from Basildon Hospital said I had to attend clinic again! In May 2022 I attended to be told the same thing!  
The dermatologist from Basildon called me up to ask for me to attend clinic in Canvey. I said I was told the 2 on my nose must be done in hospital. They assured me that the plastic surgeon was attending the clinic and was fully capable of removing the lesions.  
I attend the Canvey clinic in August 2022. I was shocked when the surgeon said it was only a biopsy! They said sometimes if they have clear margins, they can remove all of it. They cut 2 chunks out of my face and told me one was 4 stitches and one was 3 stitches. As they was operating on me, the nurse said the surgeon had nicked their finger. They carried on cutting me and never changed the blade! They then said to the nurse that maybe they should change their gloves. The nurse said that they didn't think it had torn the glove.  
When the stitches were removed, there was 3 on one side and 2 on the other! This does not inspire confidence in me at all. I was also told it’s an 8 week wait for the biopsy! The stitches are now out and there are no clear margins as he has left part of the lesion still there. I have lost confidence in the hospital completely and they have ignored my messages for a callback and nobody answers and the phone often gets cut off after several rings!

readBy.name: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

author: HGpreg
title: Maternity services FVRH
body:
I have suffered from HG throughout my pregnancy and have been in and out of hospital with dehydration and I am on a range of anti sickness medication. Yesterday I was severely dehydrated, pulsing heart, vomiting, had reduced fetal movement and hadn’t been able to keep anything down for over 24 hours, so phoned mat triage. Unfortunately, it took me 20 mins to get an answers on the phone and then I was put on hold. When my call was finally handled, they couldn’t find me on the system because I’m cross boundary and was told I should be seen but it was a long wait. When arriving at mat triage, the team were very short staffed and busy with the waiting area being standing room only. Due to vomiting, I was moved to another waiting room and was then left for 4 hours before being moved up to the labour ward to be seen, as mat triage had now closed. I then waited another 30 mins to be seen and was finally put on a monitor and was told someone would be with me in a few minutes, however I had to wait another 40 mins before being seen. There was a clear breakdown in communication as the midwives seemed to be confused as to what I was there for, my symptoms, who had my urine sample and what had happened. The midwives were all apologetic and lovely and told me I was severely dehydrated and would likely be kept in. One midwife explained that they had been phoned to start their shift early due to the staffing issues within the department.  
When I was finally seen by a doctor, I was told I was dehydrated, had a three plus ketones in my urine and to go home and have a nice meal (I have not been able to eat a meal in months, which I had explained numerous times). The quality of care I have received has been horrendous and there seems to be a lack of understanding around how dangerous, embarrassing and debilitating HG can be. I was left feeling vulnerable, neglected and dreading going into labour.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
NHS Forth Valley
Scottish Government

author: Mum26
title: Smoking at RHC playground
body:
My wee one has respiratory issues and I am unable to take him to the RHC playground between treatments due to the constant presence of smokers and the effect this has on his health and well being.  
I was so hopeful when the law was changed to make smoking within 15m of hospitals illegal and liable to fines. However I was so disappointed to see that people were smoking at the children's hospital bike shed and covered areas at the playground. This went unchallenged by hospital staff.  
This was the ideal opportunity for the health board and RHC management to make a positive change for families like me (and the wider community).

title: Prothesis Nurses
body:

My confidence was at an all-time low and I was dreading the appointment. However, Nicola and Elaine, the prosthesis nurses, were absolutely wonderful to me! I went to Ninewells first- and cant remember much about my time there. I was then was transferred to Perth Royal Infirmary (PRI) after 2 days.  
When I arrived at PRI I could not talk or walk and struggled with movement and sensation on my right side. With the treatment I received, I have almost returned back to my old self.

author: Mauresmo
title: My experience with my daughter - exemplary care
body:
My daughter has a severe learning disability and is non verbal.  
I had to take her to Altnagelvin Area Hospital today for a scheduled dental X-ray but she has had a swollen ankle for a couple of days so I thought that I should have it x rayed too.  
I was prepared to go and have the dental X-ray done and then make my way to A&E to have her ankle seen to. I decided to give Clionagh (disability liason nurse) a call to let her know that we were coming to the hospital and ask if we could make use of the sensory room in A&E in order to make the experience less daunting for my daughter.  
Clionagh kindly offered to call X-ray and ask them to do both the X-rays while we were there to save a long wait in A&E. They immediately said that they would be happy to help. It was simply a matter of calling our GP to ask them to do the referral.  
Clionagh duly called the GP and they were happy to oblige and sent the referral through promptly.  
My daughters ankle X-ray was done almost immediately and she was treated with kindness and courtesy throughout by all the staff from receptionist to radiographer.  
I went to the hospital prepared to stay for several hours when, in actual fact, we were there for less than an hour! I think it’s important to acknowledge the help and exemplary care that we received today.  
Thanks to Clionagh for her intervention and thanks to the staff in the X-ray department for their kindness and efficiency.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, MBBS (Medicine) 2021
Public Health Agency

title: Effective and efficient nursing care
body:
I went to Vic minors injuries for my hand worried it might be broken.

Hope his managers appreciate him and the others within the minor injuries unit.

author: homamzn44
title: I want them to improve for the next mother
body: This wasn’t my first baby, it was my third and unfortunately was not the first bad experience I have had. Especially with postnatal care. For some background to my previous experience, with my first when in labour, I felt the need to push too soon. The staff member with me at the time referred to their senior midwife, who said it's their first baby, they don't know what they're talking about. My baby was stuck and it resulted in urgent action being taken when the doctor came to see how I was getting on. Staff at the time forgot to recheck my bloods after a blood loss and I became very unwell for months because of this and I believe that this caused or was part of the cause of postnatal depression. My second baby, I was almost sent home again without my bloods being checked, even when I kept asking. As I was packing they came in to tell me I needed a blood transfusion. This pregnancy - my third pregnancy and the one this is mainly about - was by far the worst experience. I wanted to have as natural a birth as possible however due to previous weights of my babies, it was a balancing act and resulted in growth scans and frequent hospital appointments to discuss said growth scans. A plan was in place for weeks. At my last visit, this all changed when I was informed that they could not locate my notes from my first birth. Somehow along the way, it had been communicated that something had occurred in my first birth that had not, and which I said had not, but I was advised to book in a c-section because they didn’t have my notes. I refused because it happened to me and I know what occurred and wouldn’t be forced. So I was booked in for an induction after them suggesting I would likely be killing myself and my baby! Their mannerisms were disgusting. This went on for a while longer, no notes, nobody could find them. I went in for my covid swabs and myself and partner were covid positive and so my induction was moved - which at one point had been deemed medically necessary to be carried out at that stage.I complained to the lead clinician after a phone call with a consultant surrounding this which caused a panic attack and having to hand my husband the phone. The consultant was entirely unreasonable and rude. When I made points they agreed but still would not change my date that was cancelled. A point of note - all NHS provided at home COVID tests were negative. So following a complaint to the lead clinician, they then begin to try and locate my notes (my personal data) again and book me back in a couple days later. Some time later, I got a call and my notes had been found. What I had said did not occur, indeed did not and telling me I was risking my life and that of my baby had been entirely uncalled for. The panic and upset that caused was for nothing. Aside from anything else, not having my notes and the NHS not being aware of where these were is a data protection issue as well as being potentially harmful to my health if something had been missed because of not having those notes. I must say, when in for my induction, throughout labour and then the emergency c-section, all staff were fantastic. Those in the operating theatre especially (who by the way had not been told about the previous positive covid test which was discovered when the anaesthesiologist came to check on me on the ward). I had not at any point through labour been treated as covid positive. I was then moved to ward 8 and put in a shared room. I text my husband to tell him where to find me, he arrived and then I was given a mask suddenly and swept away into a private room where we were not told about why we had been moved. My mother in law had visited and left, and my partner went home to check our dogs. At that point a midwife came in and said I could not have visitors, after the fact. I queried about my husband and was told he wouldn’t be able to come back. I was in a locked off private room alone after a section with a newborn, how would anyone feel? My husband called to query and complain. After this, he was allowed back and again we could have visitors if we wanted. The main nursery nurse I had was rude and not at all understanding of the needs of a mother. When my baby was crying and my husband not there one night and I needed help, nobody came and i was not comfortable calling for them. Nobody brought me any water until the morning and I was beyond thirsty and began drinking horrible tasting tap water. A health care assistant at one point entered my room in full PPE and put my crockery and cutlery into a clinical waste bag, throwing it in. In front of me with my newborn present. I have worked for the NHS. This is not acceptable but the staff have denied it occurring. Why would I make this shocking behaviour up? Actually the staff have denied all, including ever placing me in a shared room and claim there is no documentation of this. Apparently it's been noted that we were very happy with the visiting conversations - which we were not. They should have call recordings to this effect. Apparently I was offered support numerous times and this is documented. I'm aware from working in healthcare that some staff document they offered assistance to tick a box when in-fact they did not. I am devastated this happy time was ruined and genuinely feel traumatised by the whole thing. All I want is an apology and for them to recognise where they went wrong and improve for the next mother. I felt like an alien.

readBy.name: NHS Forth Valley
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Scottish Government

author: Lmca
title: Lack of service
body:
I had a smear test in November 21’ and was told in my results that I had pre cancerous cells and would require a colposcopy and I would have an appointment within 8 weeks.  
4 weeks later I received a letter that told me the wait was now 30weeks which would have taken me up to August 22.  
Since the start of August I have had no communication regarding this, I cannot get through to health records or the gynaecology department at the Royal Alexandra Hospital (RAH) and I have now been sent a letter to go for another smear test which I assume is to check the results of the Colposcopy which hasn’t taken place.  
I have had no communication from the NHS since January 22 regarding this and my attempts to contact have been unsuccessful.

author: sagittakz63
title: Emergency visit to Opthalmology
body:
Following a scheduled eye test (I’ve already thanked the Opticians) and experiencing some loss of vision I was given a ‘rush’ appointment to Queen Margaret Hospital Dunfermline. I was seen by the On Call Opthalmologist Dr Mair.  
It didn’t help that I was also in a deal of pain/ limited mobility due to my Rheumatoid Arthritis.  
I cannot thank Dr Mair enough for her care and manner and especially, in light of the confusing symptoms, her way of explaining what may or may not be the way ahead.  
Subsequently, with my sight worsening I have again been seen at short notice by both Dr Mair and her boss Dr Styles. I believe I present as a what’s-going-on-here? patient. Believe me, I do appreciate that if a Consultant can use the word ‘stumped’ but still pull out the stops to identify the causes, I’m in good hands. Thank you again.  
PS - Dr Mair must be the best taker-of-blood samples ever. Not a mark!

author: Eeoyretigger
title: Excellent Care
body:
In early September I was admitted to Greetwell Ward via A & E Lincoln County Hospital with pain in my jaw, gums and struggling to breathe and swallow even pain relief as the swelling was obstructing my wind pipe.  
I arrived at A&E and I was fast tracked through the system and soon started on pain relief steroids and antibiotics x2 intravenously whilst waiting for a bed which happened in a very quick time of 6 hrs ,I had arrived in the morning and was in a bed on the ward in the afternoon following a CT Scan.  
Whilst I got zero sleep as I am noise sensitive and aggravated in hospital situations, I commend the support and care given to me by the 24/7 team on Greetwell Ward. There was excellent communication and care from the nursing staff, Junior Doctors and I had quite a few in involved in my care.  
I would also like to highlight the excellent support and care given especially by the health care support workers and those orderlies serving the food. Their attention to detail and to my needs was impeccable despite the many pressures all staff were under.  
My only disappointment as a Senior Care Assistant was that junior staff failed to understand the different needs of patients. Especially elderly patients with visual impairments, who found it difficult to use their buzzers and often would not get offered drinks because they were never asked .  
If I could ask for the Lincoln County Hospital to consider their stance on inclusion and how a person with noise sensitivity could be better supported in this situation.

readBy.name: United Lincolnshire Hospitals NHS Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Pedro C2
title: Shoulder surgery
body:
Shoulder surgery carried out at Queen Margaret Hospital Fife September 2022.  
I have no complaints at all. Treated brilliantly by all staff. I was asked to come in early. Arrived and after a few routine questions by staff I was at my bed an hour earlier than my original scheduled appointment time. Was spoken to by Dr Sharma and Dr Li. A full explanation was given on the procedure and the consent forms signed. Taken for surgery.  
Back to my ward later that day and seen by staff and the physio therapist. Given tea and toast. Again spoken to by nurses to confirm I was feeling ok and given painkillers.  
Released at in the evening with full instructions on post op exercises etc and contact numbers should I feel unwell.  
I received to follow up calls the following day ensuring I was fine, one of which was the local physio therapist to which I’m booked in for 1 week after my op.  
Fabulous treatment from all.  
Thank you everybody that had an involvement with me at QMH.

title: C-section team were fantastic
body:
I came to Daisy Hill Hospital as I was having a planned section. The C-section team were absolutely fantastic. They kept me properly informed about everything that was going on. They were all incredibly calm and relaxed throughout which kept my nerves at ease and they were also fantastic at working together in a team.  
Up on the Maternity Ward the care has just been absolutely amazing. All the staff have been incredibly attentive to all of my needs. It has to be said that the staff are always very open with you, incredibly friendly as well as always there for you when you need them for something. Any communication I have had with staff has also been great. I really cannot single out any staff members as they have all been brilliant.  
I have no suggestions for improvement - this is my second child now and the care I have received at Daisy Hill Hospital has been excellent.

title: My experience has been 100%
body:
After developing chest pains, I came to the Emergency Department at Daisy Hill Hospital. Everything here was 100% and all the staff were dead on.  
I was then transferred to the Cardiac Unit at Craigavon Area Hospital. Everything was absolutely spot on here and all the staff were amazing.  
Following this, I was transferred back to the Coronary Care ward at Daisy Hill. Everything has been 100% here on this ward. The staff have all been good. They are great at communicating with you and a lot of what you ask for you get. The attitude of staff members is again 100% and they are all very polite.  
When it comes to the food - it hasn't been too bad. Although I have to say it is much better than the food in the Royal.  
I have no suggestions for improvement - except maybe a bigger TV on the ward.

author: eridanuspf43
title: Mastectomy operation
body:
I had my mastectomy operation date changed, and that was fine with me, as obviously it’s a case of ‘the sooner, the better with the removal of cancer.  
I was told to attend the day surgery unit in Wishaw General and all the staff were lovely. Very professional and put me at ease.  
It was the first time I’d met with my surgeon as I’d been on the list for a different surgeon until the date was changed. The surgeon and their team were also fantastic.  
There was only one thing that detracted from my positive experience of the mastectomy and that is that I had been assured by my original surgeon and two separate breastcare nurses, that I would have support on the ward with the expected body image issues and be given something they refer to as a ‘softie’ or a ‘comfie’ to be placed (with the support of a nurse who’d take my bra measurement and provide the right size) into the newly empty bra cup.  
Because my operation was done in the day surgery unit, they had no knowledge that a ‘softie’ was required in my case and my only option was to leave the ward feeling very self conscious about my operation and missing breast.  
One of the nurses was kind enough to fashion a bra filler out of crepe bandage, because my remaining breast is quite large and I genuinely felt uneven and like a bit of a freak.  
Obviously the quick fix was okay for the walk to the car, but it wasn’t at all appropriate as a temporary ‘softie’ because it was the wrong density, didn’t fit well and would have aggravated the wound if I left it in situ.  
It’s very important that the breastcare nurses and day surgery nurses have better communication, so that this doesn’t happen to other people in my position. Aftercare and the provision of advice on bra wearing and a softie after the operation is imperative for the best chance of wound healing and the mental health issues involved with mastectomy.  
Yesterday, my body image and perception of myself in relation to my personal relationships was changed forever and I was in a very vulnerable state, so to not have the temporary prosthesis to use wasn’t ideal.  
I’m extremely proactive in trying to heal myself and wanted to follow everything expected of me to the letter, so the fact that nobody had any idea what I was talking about when I asked about a softie for my scar site was saddening.  
I’m now left using a balled up pair of socks which are somewhat like I would imagine a softie to feel like, just so that I can provide support to the wound and the remaining breast, which will hopefully promote healing.  
The protocol for getting measured for a real prosthetic is commenced after the two week initial wound healing period, so I will now have to call my breastcare nurse on Monday and I expect that she’ll be able to give me the softie I’m relying on to make my son feel less distressed about my operation. I’ve done my best all along to downplay the seriousness of the cancer and treatment because he’s a child, but not having the proper temporary disguise for the missing breast, hasn’t helped. It’s obvious to anyone who looks at me right now that I only have one breast and I was assured by all the pre operative professionals I spoke to that I would not, at any time, have this issue.  
My breastcare nurse is based in East Kilbride and I live in Airdrie so it’s an inconvenience that was completely avoidable for me, that I now need to get someone to give me a lift through to East Kilbride, to pick up something that was supposed to be provided to me as a standard part of my procedure.  
I wanted to tell you my story, so that you might consider this problem in the case of future mastectomies in the day surgery unit.  
I must reiterate that all the staff were wonderful and it was only after I asked about what to do about my empty bra cup, that their attitude changed a bit .Although I was not in any way complaining or blaming, quite a few nurses started to act defensive and I felt like I was being a nuisance and asking too many questions too, which changed my positive experience a bit.  
, which changed my positive experience a bit.  
I still gave them a card and a couple of boxes of chocolates and thanked them profusely, but my experience would have been GREATLY improved by just not having to feel like a trouble maker for simply asking nicely for the thing that I had been repeatedly told I would be given after the procedure.  
Today I have concerned family members visiting and without the pre planned use of the temporary prosthetic, I feel much less comfortable about putting on the brave face I’m going to put on. I probably didn’t explain that right, but maybe you know what I mean.  
Immediately post op is a make or break time for how people process this process this operation, mentally. I would have benefited greatly from better support.  
Thank you for your time and thank you for everything else involved in my diagnosis and treatment.

readBy.name: NHS Lanarkshire
Scottish Government

author: Anoyt98
title: Quick & not so painful
body: Checked in for my 4th covid vaccine and this years flu vaccine. Check in went smooth, was assigned a booth, Nurse went through my details thoroughly and vaccinator checked again. Felt very relaxed and vaccines where quick & not so painful. I sat for 5 mins then had to use the toilets. Can I just say the ladies toilets at Eddlewood public hall are fantastic. Very, very clean and tidy, hand towels and toilet roll stocked, also period products. I find this extremely positive. So well done to the staff!! I work in a hospital and I can tell you the toilets in there are nowhere near as clean as the ones at the public hall.

body: I have been in hospital for 2 weeks today under observation. The staff in here are simply wonderful- from the tea ladies to the nurses to the consultants, each and every person is so caring and compassionate. author: eridanusgw89
title: Getting no support
body:
I'm with High Wycombe branch and my key worker was told by me that I lost my phone, so had no way of contacting them. But none the less, they stopped my script and that was it, no letter, nothing. I think it's not been a good experience for me as it left me ill and with no other option but to use, as I have no job and no car at the moment. In my opinion, the One Recovery Bucks in High Wycome has gone downhill in the last few years.  
The support is not there in my experience. They act more like a teacher or boss if you don't feel comfortable talking about your feelings and answer their questions. My friend had issues with their script. The care and support is just not there anymore like it should be. Us addicts have lots of mental and emotional issues and our support network just kicked us to the curb. I'm lucky I have family around. I feel sorry for those who don't because this group is no support.

author: lyraqm44
title: Recovery
body:
On my arrival at the service I was scared, anxious and worried about the other patients and how they would receive me. I was really buzzing about the chance I had been given to detox and wanted to make it work, I was looking forward to it. I had multiple emotions going on from happiness to huge anxiety and fear. Looking back now my admission was a blur and I just wanted to stay in my room and recluse. The staff supported me through this time and gave me space to ground myself. My treatment was started that day after close monitoring and I felt safe that I was being cared for professionally. My accommodation was clean tidy and tidy, with clean bed linen provided regularly. The food was nice and cooked freshly every day.  
There have been some negative aspects to my stay for example having to deal with my anxiety and a feeling of claustrophobia to the middle and latter part of my stay. There have been some issues around nightly well being checks and how certain staff did those, but I discussed this with other staff members and the problem was dealt with. Overall my detox was 85% positive and 15% negative but this 15% improved once the issue was addressed.

title: Waiting time for reviving treatment for accute pain
body: Called NHS 24 for accute pain due to existing condition . On hold for an hour and fifteen minutes . Then spoke to nurse who refer me to out of hours for pain relief , they would also emphasise the urgency due to pain experienced . 1 hour 20 later and still not contact . So from making the initial call at 2.11pm to now at 4.57 ( where I am sitting waiting in the hospital car park to receive pain relief ) it is almost 21/2 hours . title: I feel very comfortable
body: I have received great care from the staff on this ward, I am just recently back from the theatre after receiving an operation, I’m hoping everything has went well, by the looks of things it has. This ward is great, I have lots of room in this bay, and I feel very comfortable. The facilities on the ward are all very accessible and are cleaned really well, the toilet and shower room are right beside me which is good.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Ozbarbiegirl
title: We firmly believe that they saved his life!
body:
My dad had a mild heart attack and was in a different hospital for several weeks before being transferred to the Jubilee.  
The level of care he received from the minute he was taken there was second to none and we firmly believe that they saved his life!  
Within an hour of being there the staff were all over his condition (which had been left to sadly deteriorate at the previous hospital) and had him booked in for an emergency heart bypass operation the following day which being a Saturday was not a usual occurrence.  
The staff from nurses to cleaners have only had my dads best interest at heart and we can’t thank them enough.

readBy.name: Golden Jubilee National Hospital

author: Island Hopper
title: Visit to A and E Altnagelvin with 80 year old Mum
body: We waited 9 hours in a dirty waiting room where there was no sense of logic or flow..no care or urgency...only to have our own painful situation shadowed by watching others who had been there much longer than us. To watch desperately sick people sitting with injured limbs, people and babies and toddlers screeching, sat for hours on end too. No food vending machines for 9 hour stay is incorrigible. A washroom with no soap and not cleaned once in the 9 hours we were there. My poor Mum feeling guilty for being there. In my opinion, this service is in a sad state of affairs and so very broken.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Ulster University, MBBS (Medicine) 2021

author: guidebe39
title: Believing in me
body:
Several months ago I sank to what I would describe as the lowest point of my life. There were many reasons for this, the main one being having no confidence in myself and not liking me anymore.  
Following a referral to inclusion I was extremely dubious & nervous about how this service could help me. I attended the pre counselling course and was surprised to find the many psychological therapies available. I’m not one for group sessions as I don’t like talking about ‘me’ but I found a type of therapy that I felt would tackle the issues I had. My perception was that I would talk about the issues I had and would be told what to do to resolve these.  
I was so wrong…..it was completely different to what I had thought. My therapist was amazing. The thing that stood out the most was the fact he just listened & listened & listened. He never interrupted, he never judged, he offered solace when I became upset, but most of all, he allowed me to be me, a person I never really understood and never felt I belonged. He offered different ways to think and deal with situations, he made me realise I don’t always have to think of a hundred solutions and never find one. I realised I couldn’t change the traumas I had experienced but by giving myself permission to acknowledge my emotions and love myself, this would start my path to having a better relationship with myself. I realise there will still be good & bad days but the therapy I have received has been invaluable and I would encourage anybody to give therapy a chance, no matter what this may entail as working in partnership has certainly helped me tremendously. I can’t thank my therapist enough for the time he has given me to believe in me.

readBy.name: Midlands Partnership NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: weasel
title: My mum had excellent care
body:
My mum was rushed into A&E last week at Croydon University Hospital and received excellent care. She was treated by A&E, AMU and CCU and all the staff were attentive, professional, and reassuring.  
I want to thank all the hardworking staff for the care they provided to my mum, we are very thankful and delighted to have her home.

author: NanaLisa
title: Amazing care during my stay in Stock Ward
body:
I had Breast Reconstruction DIEP Flap in September 2022.  
Mr Banwell was my consultant. Unfortunately for me I had a few complications after initial surgery so had to go to theatre a further 2 times. As you can imagine my husband and family were extremely worried, but Mr Banwell kept my husband updated throughout and the end result was great.  
When I was finally taken to Stock Ward I was treated respectfully and had the most amazing care from all members of staff including the physiotherapist.  
I was able to leave hospital after a few days with continuing care at the end of a telephone and outpatient appointments. I hope this gives reassurance to anyone going forward.  
Broomfield hospital staff are in my opinion true heroes and I can never thank them enough.

author: woodpeckerwb56
title: Very pleased with the service and standard of care I received
body:
I went into hospital for vascular surgery and all I can say is how well I was looked after and how very pleased I was with the service and standard of care I received.  
It was all extremely good, very good communication and happy with all that they did for me.

author: errandtg38
title: Full explanations for my urology procedure
body:
The staff were excellent because they were well informed, made me feel relaxed, and explained the procedure.  
They allayed any fearful preconceptions that l had, and gave me a comprehensive explanation of possible side effects after the procedure.  
Another thing that impressed: everyone of the staff was on first name terms, with no titles.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: BPBear
title: Not being understood
body:
I applied to IAPT Back on track as a carer who is struggling. I had already tried the local carers network but because I and the person I care for live in different boroughs they could not help. I have a diagnosis of bipolar and am currently under the temporary care of mental health services for a medication change. Because of this I was turned down for support as a carer, even though this meds change is completely separate from the short term talking therapy support I am asking for. In the letter informing me of this decision, I was referred to my GP but it is my GP who gave me the link to apply to IAPT in the first place. I would have preferred that some one contacted me to fully understand my case.  
[Unhappy with 'Appointments']

body:

author: Malcolm85
title: Care at Ward 33 Victoria hospital Kirkcaldy
body:
After falling in street I ruptured the quad tendon in my knee.  
After be taken by ambulance to The Victoria hospital in Kirkcaldy I was admitted to ward 33 and underwent an operation to repair the damage.  
From the very beginning every single nurse, doctor and Physiotherapist we're absolutely magnificent.  
However two stood out as extra special. Staff Nurse Becky and Advanced Nurse Practioner Gemma. Gemma had also by coincidence stopped at the scene in advance of the ambulance arriving and helped despite the weather being absolutely horrendous. Becky was just that bit extra special and unbelievably good at her job.  
It's a fantastic team at ward 33 and all should be very proud of the job they do. They made what was a traumatic time a bit easier.

Fife Health & Social Care Partnership

author: M-2000
title: Incredible Compassion from a member of staff
body:
I have been working with Lucy who does peer support at my Health Centre. I have so much admiration for her. She has so much compassion for her patients and has went above and beyond to help me. She has done so much to help better my situation/condition. I have had negative experiences with my care in the past with another clinic but Lucy has actively helped and supported me to get better.  
I will forever be thankful.

author: WG301047
title: A department that treats patients with great empathy
body:
I was referred after having lost hearing overnight and having been told it was wax in my ear. After getting the wax removed at the local chemist, who also raised questions re problems of the type of wax they were removing and after over 6 weeks and no sign of it getting better, I got an appointment within a week of the referral which was a big surprise.  
I was advised, after hearing tests and examination of my ears, that I had a hole in my inner ear due to an infection. This was all done and explained very well and all my questions answered with no problems by a lovely consultant and the staff in his clinic.  
After a few weeks my hearing deteriorated very badly once again overnight. Upon calling the ENT department, I was told to come that afternoon to allow them to look at my ears.  
Once again treated extremely well and everything explained again, and I was referred for a scan to check if there were any further problems that were not being picked up.  
Again only 2 weeks before I got the scan and only a further 2 weeks before a response about what it had found and that it hadn't shown anything serious or life threatening.  
Again appt received within 4 weeks with Mr Walker at ENT. I had previously read a report about him that was displayed in the waiting room at ENT, and had commented to my husband that they had made him sound like a saint and that I definitely didn't believe that, possibly because of the experience I had and was still having with a consultant at the same hospital but in another department!  
At my appointment I found that, OK Mr Walker was not a saint, but wasn't far off it. He is a lovely down to earth person who puts his patients at ease right away and treats them with sympathy and respect and goes through all possibilities in depth and takes your views seriously and again sympathetically.  
It was agreed he would try grommets to see if this would help and after getting advanced hearing tests and results being received by him within 2 weeks of my original appointment with him, I was in the department getting grommets inserted by him.  
Although he had told me very fully what would happen, I was a bit apprehensive as it was being done under local anaesthetic. He was fantastic, explaining what he was going to do and checking when he was doing the procedure that it wasn't too painful and that I was coping OK. It was almost pain-free and I just couldn't believe how caring he was.  
I am 74yrs of age and get very angry at times with some people in the medical profession who make me feel, because of my age, that I am senile and an inconvenience. But at no time did I feel that with anyone at the ENT department. I felt that nothing was a problem with them and that I, the patient, was the most important person at every point.  
Having a problem with your health is not a great experience but I am left feeling that here was a department that treated their patients with great empathy and understanding. A lot of this I think comes from having a Head of Department who knows how genuinely to show his staff how he appreciates their work, which then spills over to how they treat the patient.  
Great department and staff xx

readBy.name: NHS Fife
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Fife Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I have such admiration for the staff on the trauma ward
body: Last Tuesday I slipped and fell on a wet floor in a coffee shop in my local town, I didn’t realise how serious the fall was and at first I didn’t want the ambulance to be called as I didn’t feel as if it was necessary. Then I realised after I tried to get myself up, that the only way I was going to be able to leave the coffee shop, was with help from the paramedics. The ambulance arrived within 10-15 minutes and I was brought over to the emergency department in Craigavon, I was given some morphine which was great as it eased some of the pain. The emergency department was so busy and the noise of all the patients was just awful I felt so sick and uncomfortable. I was placed on a really flat bed, it was more like a stretcher I found it hard to move my head to the side, I was left lying like this for a while and found it hard to breathe I almost choked. I have such admiration for the staff on the trauma ward, there all great at their job and I don’t think they are praised enough. The food on the ward hasn’t been great, the only thing that has been okay, has been the vegetable soup and mashed potatoes. In terms of nutrition, you wouldn’t get very much from the food they offer. The ward has some good facilities but I think there could be a big improvement in the equipment that's provided. I found it very difficult trying to exercise whilst I was lying on the bed and couldn’t get up, I didn’t feel as if these exercises were helping and I was just very uncomfortable. I think if the hospital had some sort of equipment that made it easier, like something to help glide your leg along whilst holding onto something, this would benefit the patients who are in the same exposition as me.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: All of my needs are being met with the help of the staff
body: I came in through the emergency department, it wasn’t too busy and because my injury was serious I got seen very quickly. The communication with the staff in ED was really good, and I was brought up to the ward shortly after. The nurses and care assistants have been providing me with the best care, all of my needs are being met with the help of the staff. This ward is very clean the cleaning staff are great, the ward is very big and they still manage to have it spotless throughout the day.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Sindy91
title: You made a horrible experience more bearable
body:
I unfortunately had to attend the Gynaecology day ward at QEUH recently as I required a surgical procedure for an incomplete miscarriage. All members of the team were very attentive, kind and compassionate.  
I had one nurse, one healthcare assistant, a doctor and a consultant caring for me. I didn't expect so many people to be looking after one patient. Unfortunately I can't remember all their names but thanks to Charge Nurse Fiona and Dr Claire. You made a horrible experience much more bearable.  
My only criticism is the location of the ward. It is very close to the labour ward and I had to walk past a new mum and baby. Although not too triggering for me, this could be a very difficult experience for a woman having a miscarriage.

readBy.name: NHS Greater Glasgow & Clyde

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The nursing staff on the ward have been a great help
body: I was recently told I would be receiving an operation, when I arrived to the hospital I was brought to the orthopedic ward straight away, I was waiting for a while and then was taken down to theatre, my operation went as planned, and I’m just glad it is all over now as I was very nervous. The staff were just excellent in the theatre, they really tried to make sure I was as comfortable and calm. The nursing staff on the ward have been a great help, I’m thankful for all that they have been doing, as right now I’m very weak and not able to do much without the help from them.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The staff have been so respectful
body: All the different members of staff I have come across on this ward have been so respectful and polite, they have been taking really good care of me and there just lovely to talk to. The food I have received on the ward has been really nice, I enjoy the porridge in the morning. The ward is very clean and the facilities are all very modern and are in good condition. The communication with the GPs and nurses has been great, I’m always being informed on what’s going on.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: whisperdr94
title: Not getting help
body: I am in my late seventies and after a recent fall where I broke my neck, back and ribs I asked if the podiatrists could visit me at home. They have refused this request, saying they don't have enough staff. My toe nails are so long that they are hurting, my feet are very swollen and I have numbness in one of my feet. I am in constant pain.
